dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Portland, home of rivers, bridges, and more parks than yo can shake a stick at. The Columbia River, spanned by the bridges, glistens a muddy brown in the sunlight; the Will off to the South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMILY ROSE T. HOPE cut her teeth on a million dollar teet ring, and it was bitter -- too bitter. It left her an old in a young woman's body.  She idly taps a cellular phone's keypad with one perfectl manicured nail as she stares through the parking level's a distant bridge -- and an approaching river barge.  The barge draws closer to the bridge. Closer. Closer stil She takes a drag off a cigarette, stubs it out, and dials phone's keypad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMADEUS T. HOPE, an older man who most assuredly broke hi teeth on a Rolls Royce, stands in a phone booth just off for the phone to ring and caressing a briefcase like it c dollars -- which it does. Nearby, idle joggers in the par obviously undercover cops. The phone rings and Amadeus li

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O./FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Amadeus T. Hope?

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O./FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Did you bring the money.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O./FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Listen carefully.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: I wish to speak to my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O./FILTERED)
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in what you wish, Mr. Hope. Just  follow directions and stick to the plan. Am I clear?

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily watches the barge move towards the bridge and readj her speaking apparatus -- it's a voice filter and it's a through this rig.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Do you see the barge approaching the bridge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amadeus squints through glass booth walls, notes the appr barge, nods.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: I see it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O./FILTERED)
dialogues.text: Walk to the bridge, throw the briefcase onto the  barge, and come back to the phone booth for further direc

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: How do I know you'll release her?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O./FILTERED)
dialogues.text: You don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETECTIVE DAN SIMS is the kind of guy who does his job we but everything always goes to hell anyway. This gives him life, but he keeps trying. He watches a fellow COP fiddle tracing equipment. Sims' less than garrulous partner, BAR on an extra set of headphones.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Shit. Cellular phone.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: What did you expect? A silver platter?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Would'a been nice. Sims stares out the van's polarized window at Amadeus, wh walking steadily out along the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: It's probably hers -- where's he going?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: To throw the money over the side.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: That's what they just told him to do. Sims, glaring, grabs for a walkie talkie.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Were you going to tell me before or after he tossed  it? Barnaby shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into walkie talkie) He's throwing the money onto the barge. I want full  surveillance -- don't lose that barge --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily's got the phone balanced precariously on one should as she flips open the trunk of a gray Mercedes Benz and e duty tape. She stands again to stare out at the distant b Amadeus, stick figure tiny with distance, heaves his brie over the side and starts back to his phone booth at a ste

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Nice throw, Dad. Joggers (i.e. under cover cops), looking like ants from  here, scramble to keep pace with the barge. Emily laughs her ankles together. The phone crackles to life.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You've got the money. Where's my daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ankles taped, Emily hops to the edge of the trunk to rumm for more bondage paraphernalia and holds the voice filter while she speaks:

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You'll find her in the trunk of her car, which is  in fifth level parking at -- She pulls a wrinkled slip of paper from her jeans pocket  and squints at it --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 352 East Tenth Street. She hangs up and, working fast now, because time is runni out, gags herself -- a real gag: stuffing, knots, the wor Lifting hand cuffs -- the final touch -- she crawls into  the car's trunk and, still clutching the handcuffs -- pre use -- slams the lid closed from the inside.  The ECHO of the slamming trunk reverberates through the  dim garage, and dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judging from the number of plain cars screaming out of pa spaces, it's a good bet they got that address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sims comes out of the van at a dead run, talking into a  walkie talkie, as undercover cars peel out, SIRENS wailin

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Odds are someone's still inside monitoring --  He glances at the distant parking structure.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They can still see us from there, turn off the god  damn sirens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes sits innocently in its parking slot. Silence -- except for the slap slap slap of approaching footsteps airy tune being whistled by the person approaching. WILL POGUE ambles nonchalantly between cars, well dressed yuppie at large, just picking up his car and heading home you'd think, until he saunters to the Mercedes, casually and a slim jim flashes in the gloom.  He's inside the car, yanking the ignition and starting th motor, between whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B.g., a helicopter drones. The barge MATE steps out of th wheelhouse, notices the briefcase on the aft deck, frowns picks it up, shakes it, opens it -- and ogles a million b

dialogues.speaker: MATE
dialogues.text: Holy shit!  He spins back to the wheelhouse -- a plea for help.

dialogues.speaker: MATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Larry! Larry! You gotta come see this! The PILOT (let's take a wild guess and assume this is Lar sticks his head out the wheelhouse cabin's door -- just a zooms down and a SHARP SHOOTER aims a high powered rifle mate. A HELICOPTER COP leans out with a megaphone.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER COP, (MEGAPHONED)
dialogues.text: This is the Portland Police Department. You with  the briefcase, set it down and put your hands on your hea

dialogues.speaker: MATE
dialogues.text: What the -- ?

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER COP, (MEGAPHONED)
dialogues.text: You in the cockpit, pull over immediately. The mate drops the briefcase and money starts fluttering  all the hell over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sharp shooter smirks at the helicopter cop in a super way --

dialogues.speaker: SHARP SHOOTER
dialogues.text: It's not a car, John, it's a boat. You don't pull  over --  -- when he sees the money take wind --

dialogues.speaker: SHARP SHOOTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Oh shit, the money! The helicopter cop pales -- still yelling through the meg

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER COP, (MEGAPHONED)
dialogues.text: -- Oh fuck, the money. You! Pick the briefcase back  up! Below, the mate wants nothing more to do with that briefc and has gotten down on his knees to say a few Hail Marys.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER COP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You with your hands over your head, pick that briefcase  up immediately!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pilot abandons the wheelhouse to try to stop the mone pell mell trail into the sky --  He stops dead when the sharp shooter brings the rifle to  bear on him -- going after the money is threatening behav The helicopter cop is still yelling through his megaphone

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER COP, (MEGAPHONED)
dialogues.text: Pick up that briefcase! You moron! Pick it up! The mate is staring up at the helicopter, eyes big, shaki his head back and forth -- no way is he touching that bri The barge, minus its pilot, hits bottom, the jolt spinnin the briefcase out along the deck --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Sims wrestles his seat belt, struggling to snap it in a mechanism that just doesn't want to work, riding shot g car careens around the corner and down the street toward

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gray Mercedes slips out the structure's exit -- as mi undercover cars careen past it on their way in -- and tur towards Sims' car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan, cursing his seat belt, glances up in time to see the Mercedes pass, does a double take and turns to read the l

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Holy shit, that's her car! Barnaby, at the wheel, speeds along in the opposite direc

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: What? Sims, still clutching his seat belt, grabs for the siren  as they hit a bump, drops the siren, grabs it again.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you said no sirens.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Turn around! That's her god damned car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, whistling casually, hears tires squeal behind him  and checks the rear view mirror -- in time to see Sims sl the undercover car.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Holy shit! Will steps on it, sliding between two more unmarked cars  that screech around corners to cut him off -- he cranks t a third --  Will drives better than well -- but he's sweating, cursin under his breath, fighting to outdistance cop cars conver to dodge incoming cars that keep adding up --

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, all this for a lousy grand theft auto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is not looking good here. Money scattered all over  the ground, all over the water, the barge pilot and mate shoes, the barge grounded in mud at an awkward angle -- a cops milling to and fro. The helicopter cop talks into a

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER COP
dialogues.text: Dan, we lost the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Sims, rocking around each curve, hangs onto his swing seat belt for dear life and yells into his radio.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you lost the money? It's on a  barge! How hard could it be to keep track of a barge?

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER COP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We didn't lose the barge. We lost the money.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake, where'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter cop stares glumly up at all those flutteri bills in the sky. . . down at all those floating bills on .

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER COP
dialogues.text: Half is air borne, and the other half sank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan's about three shades of purple, still clinging to his dysfunctional seat belt, yelling into the radio --

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Well fish it out! -- When the car slows. Dan rounds on Barnaby, the driver.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you slowing down for!

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: We lost him. Sims looks up from the radio at the abandoned street.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: God damn it, where are the helicopters.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: They lost him too. Sims slumps.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: I don't believe this. Barnaby shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: He can't have gone far. They'll pick him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warehouse is large, immaculate, and dark -- ground le windows are painted black and barred. Shelves hold engine beat up Porsche Speedster sits in a corner. Loft steps le above.  An electric garage door slides open, triggering a ceiling light, and Emily's Mercedes glides in. The garage door sh Will climbs from the car to run a shaky hand through his B.g., a helicopter DRONES. He lets out an explosion of br frowning at the ceiling, WILLing the copter away.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Jesus. He pats the car.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who'd you belong to, sweetheart? The president or  what? He checks the car, inside and out, admiring the interior, checking underneath the chassis.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Last job, and I nab the president's car. It figures. He pops the trunk -- there's Emily, bound and gagged, loo the worse for the ride, glaring up at him -- it might hav her cuffing her arms behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! He slams the trunk.  Muffled POUNDING inside. He opens the trunk cautiously,  to stare incredulously at Emily.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (MUFFLED)
dialogues.text: Mmmmphmmmphmmmphmmmph!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I don't need this. He lowers the trunk lid and scrubs his face with a weary  hand.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (MUFFLED)
dialogues.text: MmmmMmmmph-ph-ph! He raises the trunk lid.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Can you breathe?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (MUFFLED)
dialogues.text: MMmmmmmmMMMphmmmmm! He nods.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Have you had water within the last twenty-four hours?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: MphMphMph!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You look healthy to me. He slams the lid, jumps into the driver's seat, and hits  the control for the garage door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Sweating, revving the engine, waiting for clearance under the door --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It's okay. She doesn't know your name. She doesn't  know the address. Nobody saw you come in. We're just goin the car somewhere for the cops to find. No. She could die Okay, we'll call the cops -- an anonymous tip. No problem a corner. Dump the car. Stay calm. Everything is all righ As the garage door opens, the helicopter DRONE fills the  warehouse. Will sits, listening to that drone in the sky, tapping th steering wheel -- he turns off the engine and listens a s closing the garage door against that sound.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Shit. INT. AMADEUS's STUDY - EVENING An ad for the house would boast five fireplaces, parking  for nine cars, two hundred feet of river frontage, a dock exceptionally expensive -- and frighteningly neat.  THOMAS PERKINS steps into the study: Thomas has scars to  prove he's been bad places and lived to not talk about th conflicts with his million dollar suit only insofar as he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amadeus, intently manicuring what looks like a perfectly  manicured Bonsai, nods.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Someone's kidnapped Emily. Perkins snorts. Amadeus pinches off a microscopic section of tree, discarding it in an empty waste basket.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: The police -- (Amadeus uses the word "police" much the  way a bull dyke says "penis")

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: You called the police.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: No. They called the police.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: They.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Well she's got your attention now, hasn't she? Amadeus shoots him a dour glance.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: I fail to see the humor in the situation, Thomas.  There's a precedent at stake here. Thomas snorts again -- no way is he believing this.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The police informed me a man drove her car away  from the pick-up zone. Thomas frowns -- less sure of himself.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: An accomplice? That doesn't sound like Emily. A peremptory KNOCK and Dan Sims pushes into the study. Th turns, giving Sims a view of the back of his head and not

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Mr. Hope, I'd love to answer phones in your foyer  all day, but this man -- Sims glowers at Thomas's back.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- is not on my roster of household staff -- or  guests.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Mr. Perkins is a private associate, Detective Sims.  He'll be taking over.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Your services are no longer necessary, Detective  Sims. If you WILL excuse us? Amadeus drops another nothing into the waste basket -- a  move not lost on Sims.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: We are not a cleaning service, Mr. Hope. We are  the police. Amadeus stares blankly, like "what's the difference?"

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: I think what Detective Sims is trying to say, Amadeus,  is you can't fire the police.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: (to Perkins) Are you sure about this? Perkins nods solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Very well, Detective Sims may maintain surveillance. Sims chokes.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: I. May.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: (to Sims) That will be all, Detective Sims. Sims stands his ground, mutely refusing dismissal.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unless you'd like to discuss the money.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: I'll be in the foyer. Sims spins for the door -- the door handle fights him.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Turn to the right, Detective Sims. Sims, crimson, turns to the right.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Detective Sims? If you're going to remain a  fixture in this household, speak to my assistant -- he'll a wardrobe check. The door slams behind Sims.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nobody holds me hostage. Perkins stares into a glass case -- one of those pedestal jobs you find museum displays in, but this holds photogra Emily at three; Emily at the military academy; Emily at  graduation; Emily at a high powered reception beside her Perkins loves that little girl.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: We'll make that clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wires run from phones to phones to black boxes -- presuma the latest in police tech surveillance -- monitored by bl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amadeus's ASSISTANT attempts to work around the squad roo squalor.  Barnaby, being a calm soul, doesn't jump when Sims slams  in.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Mr. Hope just fired us. Shocked silence from the cops -- sounds perfectly reasona to Hope's assistant, though.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE'S ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: You'll be leaving, then. Dan stares at the assistant, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: No we won't be leaving!

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Can he do that?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: No he can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: (aside to the cop) We're the police, Corey.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Let's get this straight. We are the police. And  we are in control here.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Not on this planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Porsche is gone. The Mercedes sits in the gloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily is in a minor fix -- and judging from the sweat and discontent factor, has been for some time. It's not easy behind you, under your legs to in front of you -- especia lying on your side in a trunk -- and Emily's stuck mid-wa She struggles again to get her hands past her feet. Strug some more. They come free. Next job is to wrench the gag away -- she tied a good gag so it's tough going, but she gets it off. She yanks stuff takes a big breath -- spits, tries to wet her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thank God. Smiling grimly at success, she extracts the handcuff key  from her front jeans pocket and releases the cuffs.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you breathe. What an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's old Porsche glides down a dimly illuminated street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's checking the neighborhood for signs of stress, and what he sees isn't good. On the corner, a cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Cop. Across the street, another cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cop. Overhead, a helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cop.  On the sidewalk, a German Shepherd --

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cop -- dog? He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't be paranoid. That is not a cop dog. He cranes his neck to stare up through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But that is definitely a cop helicopter. He eyes the passing cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that is definitely a cop car. Another cruiser sits quietly on the corner, lights out,  but there's a guy in uniform in the car all right.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cop cop cop. Will jerks the steering wheel hard, swerving down a dark  street and away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily searches around the trunk lid's key slot -- frustra not finding what she wants, then finding it -- a small ho
There's a piece of metal blocking the mechanism that woul usually allow someone to open the trunk from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Why does it always have to be the hard way? She squirms around to face the back of the trunk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impeccable grounds, impeccable buildings -- except for on the corner of which has been reduced to rubble by an expl marks are any indication.  Thomas Perkins, hands clasped behind his back, rolls forw and backward on the balls of his feet, studying the rubbl Emily (young) stands beside him, dressed "academy," suitc by her feet, and grins, proud.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: You're lucky no one was in there. Emily's offended.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: That wasn't luck. I called.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Voice I.D. Emily grimaces chagrin.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: That won't happen again. Thomas lifts her suitcase and strides across impeccable  lawn, towards a faraway and expensive automobile with tin

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: You won't call? Awful messy, when bodies blow. She stumps along at his side.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: I won't use a cold phone.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Emily, if we could keep you in school long enough  to get an education, you'd have a real future in Secret S They're at the car. He opens the passenger door for her.  She pulls out a cigarette and lights up.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: I don't need a future. I'm rich. Thomas plucks the cigarette from her mouth, grinds it und his heel, and extends his open palm, waiting. She glares, sighs, and hands over the pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas drives. Young Emily broods in injured silence.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: He could have come. Probably playing with those  damn trees.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Maybe he doesn't appreciate paying for a new wing. Injured silence.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what this means.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Uh oh.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Back to Catholic school.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Nuns? Again?

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: It's going to take a while for me to get you in  anywhere else.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Nuns are the worst.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Look in the glove box. Emily brightens and digs, coming up with a gift wrapped  box.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, Emily. Emily shoots him a grateful smile, reads the card, grimac

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Uncle Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: It's from your father.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: It's a nice lie. Thanks for remembering. She tears wrapping.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: You're locked in a room. What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Check windows.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: The windows are barred.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Check doors.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: The doors are locked.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Check the ceiling. This is a very old routine, almost sing song.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Ceiling's clean. Emily lifts a delicate necklace from the wrapping.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: This is beautiful, Uncle Thomas.  She leans over, kisses his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: I don't want to play today. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don't you take me out to dinner, Uncle Thomas? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's my birthday. More silence. Emily sighs.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hate rooms. Let's do explosives.  He cocks an eyebrow at her -- explosives are not a good  subject right now.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: We're doing rooms.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Okay, rooms, but you have to buy me a real  drink. He snorts laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes' back seat pops loose and Emily, scuffed, cr from the trunk, over the back seat, into the car's interi

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You owe me a drink, Thomas. The first thing she reaches for is the Mercedes' cellular phone. The cord is cut.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, you creep. She pulls her purse from the trunk, rearranges the back  seat, and considers a cigarette -- sniffs the air, wrinkl her head sorrowfully, and puts the cigarette away -- befo of the car to survey her surroundings. No phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will steers down a dark street he knows by heart -- takes an alley by rote, a short cut, passes a sign: "Portland I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Porsche idles, headlights illuminating Will as he sho aside a fence marked "Airport Personnel Only" -- He pulls the car into an abandoned lot off the runway, se onto the car's hood with a weary sigh, stress falling awa up at planes taking off for Somewhere Else.  And watching his face, you know he wants to be going to  Somewhere Else -- has wanted that for all his life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever designed this place was more than security consci Bars and locks on what few windows there are, each requir strokes the bars in disgust, shoves a finger through to s in the black paint covering the glass surface.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. There're a couple of doors on the ground floor. First one a bathroom. She checks it out. Nothing in there but toile sink, and soap.  The second door is locked. She pads upstairs to study the door to the living quarter -- also locked. Not with a household doorknob. With a key

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What a control freak. She turns to study the garage door. No buttons for gettin this baby open -- ceiling and door mechanisms out of reac down, barred, keyed, bolted. She pads to a tool bench and rummages in its drawers --  the only things not locked down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's still watching those planes -- but he's calmer, mo together, and it's time to shake it off.  Moving stiffly, he climbs off the hood, walks around to  climb into the porsche's driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starting the engine, shooting one more "Wait for me, I'm  coming back" grimace at those rumbling planes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Another day. Another life. He pulls out and away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, surrounded by tools, works to disassemble the lock on the living quarters door -- this is one killer lock.  The tool slips, stabs into her finger -- adding to a grow assortment of insults to what used to be a perfect manicu the injured digit into her mouth, studies the nicks, cuts with contempt.  A police SIREN flares outside.  She brightens, till the siren FADES into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: To protect and serve. Yeah, right. She rises stiffly, shoves sweaty hair off her forehead,  glares angrily at the lock -- which looks intact as hell and pads to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Porsche glides to the warehouse's garage door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will triggers the garage door with the opener that never  leaves his side -- preferably, as high tech a coded mecha on this green earth, when it comes to garage door openers open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily's on the toilet when the electric garage door HUMS, b.g.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No! It's hard to hurry these things up, but she's ready to pe her jeans to get out of there -- she reaches automaticall toilet, jerks her hand back.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What, am I nuts? Struggling to get her pants put to rights as she stumbles to the door --

dialogues.speaker: MAIN WAREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Will guides the Porsche into the slot beside the Mercedes swings out of the Porsche, approaching the Mercedes, as t starts down, pauses --  He doesn't want to open that damn trunk. He eyes it, appr

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. He pops the trunk. It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh shit. He stares around the warehouse -- nothing -- spins to eye the closing garage door in horror.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! He smacks the control, halting the door in mid-close, duc under it to stare up and down the street of a run down wa Emily slips from the bathroom, working her way stealthily along the wall towards the open door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God damn it! An OLD WOMAN stops picking through a dumpster to glare de at him. He rakes a hand through his hair -- Emily's almost to the open door -- Will turns, ducking back inside -- looking both ways -- Emily, busted, lunges for the opening -- He lunges to cut her off --  It's a flying, freewheeling tackle -- they hit the concre floor -- inside -- and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the door, the old woman gawks. WILL and emily Will's fighting to hold Emily down as he clicks the garag door opener -- the door starts going up --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Damn it! Clicking again -- going down -- Fighting -- it's not a sure thing who's winning here --  she kicks the door's bottom edge -- going up -- He's cursing, hitting buttons -- going down -- She's kicking -- there's a lot of defense training in tho kicks -- which is unfortunate for Will's jaw -- going for with that foot -- He heaves, dragging them both backwards across concrete,  out of reach -- and the door slams closed. Silence. Will rolls onto his toes, breathing heavy, waiting for th next attack. Emily stares at the closed door in disgust, rubs her conc burned elbow.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: If you were smart, you would have pulled that stunt  when I pulled in.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I am smart. I had to pee. Not what he was expecting -- and he almost laughs, stops  when he touches his injured chin.  Wincing -- that elbow hurts -- she studies him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This place is harder to get out of than a convent.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: How'd you get out of the trunk? She surveys the Mercedes, the warehouse, him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You're not a kidnapper. You're a thief. Will snorts.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And the handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Hah. You were after the car.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Lady, you're giving me a headache. Who are you? She smiles, all winsome charm.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Tell you what. Give me the car keys, let me out  of here, and this'll be our little secret? Deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily sits on the commode, handcuffed again, this time to the sink. She's wearing pants this time, too, but that do cheer her up.  Will, flaunting a new and improved jaw injury, smiles gri and pockets the handcuff key.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You scum sucking, arrogant, peg-headed, sadistic
Will touches his jaw gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I liked you better in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I hope you go bald. A doorbell CHIMES above in the living quarters.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh, hell. He shuts the bathroom door -- on a few stifled yells --  and punches an intercom button on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yep. Will winces.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Plates ring a bell? Maybe tags? Maybe you were supposed  to be at my place five hours ago?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh. Great.  (he doesn't sound great) Hang on -- I'll be right up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old woman from the dumpster stalks, stiff backed, to  a parked police cruiser and raps on the window. A startle it down. She stares him straight in the eye, daring him t swept hair.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: I would like to report a case of domestic violence.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: You need to call it in. I'm on special assignment.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, while I pull out my portable phone.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: You want a ride downtown, Sister?

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: There is a man beating his wife down the street. The patrolman winces. She radiates indignation. He lifts  his radio.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Central, I've got a report of domestic violence  in the neighborhood. Request backup. Over.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Negative, 223. All cars in the vicinity on special  assignment. I'll have to send someone else out. Over. The patrolman rolls his eyes at the old woman.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: (to old woman) What'd I tell you? She snorts.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into radio) Central, there is a man beating his wife down the  street. Over. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sit tight, 223. I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Uncle) JOE POGUE is a pretty good indication of what Wil going to grow up to be, if Will doesn't get on one of tho quick. Not that Joe's a bad guy -- he isn't -- but he's g a bottle, and a tired stoop to his shoulders that says ba on his doorstep one too many times. Will opens the door, ready to say something appropriate,  like maybe this is a bad time -- but doesn't get the chan

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mary, and Joseph. Where have you been? Joe barges right in, waving a crinkled up brown paper sho bag under Will's nose -- about the size and shape of lice

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh god, I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You forgot? You forgot? I thought you were in jail. Stalking to the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He forgot. You got anything to drink around here? The question's moot, as Joe's got his beer and is headed  for the door to downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you get her? Will panics for a quick second.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Her?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The car?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh, right, the car. Yeah, I got her. Joe, much to Will's chagrin, is headed straight for the  door to downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well let's take a look. Joe stops at the door, studying the knob, which is loose.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When are you going to quit this business, Will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, at a loss, shrugs. Joe snorts and studies the wareh side of the doorknob and lock. Scratched.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I thought. Last job, my ass. Joe stomps down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, stroking the Mercedes, whistles. Will attempts to ar his hands in some sort of natural pose and look nonchalan

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She's pretty.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I don't think I can unload her. Joe's head snaps up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Why? What's wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Long story.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Then it'll have to wait -- Joe smacks the bag and beer into Will's numb hands.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There're your papers, tags, and plates -- whether  or not you can unload her -- and there's my beer. I gotta a man about a horse. Joe's on his way, steamrolling right up to that bathroom  door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Uncle Joe? Joe's hand's on the doorknob, turning --

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah? The door's opening --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Nothing. Emily, sitting on the commode, shoots Joe one wide, fake, frosty smile, and waves at him with her free hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mary, and Joseph! Joe simultaneously leaps up, backward, and slams the door He stands, hand on knob, thinking for a moment, before tu the stairs and starting back up for the living quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's sitting at the table, stone cold still. Will's fill a coffee pot with water, just as quiet.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Get me another beer, Son. Will gets the beer, pops it open, sets it down beside Joe empty. Joe drains it, then sets the can carefully down on

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pardon me for intruding in your affairs, Will, but  there is a girl downstairs chained to the commode. Will nods, pouring water into the coffee maker.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course, it's nice to see you with a girl, Will.  I've been kinda worried about you in the girl department

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will ogles Joe, mouths "In the girl department?" -- coffe splatters from the coffee machine -- Will jams the pot in the stream.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it was somewhat of a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I think I'll be heading home now, Will. Joe stands and heads creakily for the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Uncle Joe, would you like to know why I have a girl  chained up downstairs? Joe thinks a moment, slowly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nope. Nope. Don't want to know nothing about it. He's at the front door, opening it, turning.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But Will?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Flowers are a good alternative. Joe closes the door behind him. Will sits at the table,  trying to take it all in. The door opens again and Joe st

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, and Will?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She's a real pretty girl, Will. Your parents would've  been proud to know you're seeing such a real pretty girl. And then he's gone. Will rises slowly and starts closing  down locks -- all keyed from the inside. There's a window the door -- barred, natch, but you can see through the up 'cause they aren't painted black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patrolman eyes back entrances to warehouse buildings. They all look pretty much the same in the gloom. The old and points.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: That's the one.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: You sure? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Across from the dumpster.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Through the patrol car's back window, you can see a secon patrol car following them as he glides down the back stre corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's climbing into his old Chevy -- a small, slumped fig in all that darkness -- when the two police cars cruise a and down the street towards the warehouse's front entranc

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.  The police cars are slowing, checking buildings --

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Go, Uncle Joe, Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's at the window, every tendon in his body pushing fo Joe to get out of there --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Don't stop, old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's leaning forward in his car, eyeing the approaching  cruisers in his rearview mirror -- casually, oh so casual mirror -- you can see the indecision in him, sitting ther mirror just a little too long -- But he starts his old car up and pulls away from the curb gliding slowly down the block --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, standing pensive by the window, watching --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Keep going, Joe, keep going --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's Chevy glides around the corner as the two cruisers  halt in front. Their doors creak open, and the patrolman COP climb out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will drags a pre-packed duffel bag from under the bed, ch to make sure a stack (we are talking a serious STACK) of and hoists the duffel, heading for the stairs.  A KNOCK sounds behind him.  Another KNOCK.  He sets the bag softly down and eyes the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay, they're serious. But how serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patrolman knocks on the door again, looks at his COMP COP, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: COMPANION COP
dialogues.text: Lights are on. The patrolman nods, starting back for his car.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Call it in and see what they say. He leans into the cruiser, pulls out the radio mike.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Central, I've got a situation here in the warehouse  district. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will hoists his duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Too damn serious for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, coming down stairs two at a time, tossing the duffe bag into the back of the Porsche, yanking the bathroom do

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You running a peek show here or what?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Up. He's undoing the handcuff on the sink, jerking her to her feet, dragging her towards the car --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Who was that old man? Shoving her headfirst through the Porsche's passenger doo he slaps the cuff to the passenger brace bar --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! God Damn It! She jerks backwards -- stuck.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Get in. She doesn't. He's headed around the car, slipping into the driver's se revving the engine as he slaps control keys to open the g pauses to stare at her, hard and cold.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can ride inside or outside the car, but either  way, when that door opens, we're leaving. Emily climbs into the car and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You're a real fun date, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You aren't my idea of a good time. The Porsche squeals out of the warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffee pot steams on its burner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe slows to a crawl, pulls the Chevy over, and sits ther idling -- tapping the steering wheel, indecisive.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mary, and Joseph. He squints at approaching headlights in the rearview mirr The approaching car slows, pulls alongside him. Natch, it a COP. The cop shines a flashlight in at Joe, rolls down Joe to roll down his window and squint into the glare.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Everything all right here?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, just fine. I just kinda lost my way. The cop's getting out. Joe winces.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Could I see some identification, please?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. Joe fumbles for his wallet, pulls out a license, extends  it with a shaky hand -- the cop eyes him, takes it, studi

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Mr. Pogue, would you please step out of the car?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Please step out of the car, Sir. Joe opens the door and climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey, I just got a little lost, is all. If you could  give me directions to the freeway --

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Have you been drinking tonight, Mr. Pogue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will winds up Highway 5, North. Emily, still cuffed to th brace bar, broods in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I can see you are a master economist of words. Will grunts, spots a lone gas station and phone booth on  an abandoned stretch, slows to pull off the highway.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a kidnapper now, you know. I mean, before,  it was just an accident, but this is definitely a hostage Silence.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, and in case you didn't notice that sign back  there? "Washington."  Silence. She shakes her head in mock chagrin.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Crossing a state line with a hostage. That's a federal  offense. Will idles in front of the phone booth, unlocks the cuffs leans across her to push open the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Get out. Emily eyes him, the phone booth, him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Get. Out? The car idles. Cold wind sweeps through the open door, ru anything not nailed down.  She sits, not moving. Comprehension dawns on his face.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh. Here. He fishes in his pocket, pulls out a quarter, smacks it  into her palm.  She studies the quarter in her palm like it's some sort  of alien relic -- slowly looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You think, after being locked up, starved, bullied!  Brow beaten! Robbed! And you forgot my purse. You think n going to give me a quarter and leave me here?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: This'll do.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Forget it. I want a cigarette. I want breakfast.  I want a shower. And I want my car. She crosses her arms. He struggles for an appropriate res

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I don't allow smoking in my car.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Are you for real? The engine idles. Will eyes the car's dimensions, gauging the feasibility  of a fight in close quarters, touches the bandage on his She smiles, smug -- his odds don't look good.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm a hardened criminal.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm Emily Rose T. Hope. And you do not want to mess  with me before I get my morning cigarette. Emily snaps her seat belt on with finality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Sims wrestles his seat belt as the undercover car scr through the warehouse district.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: I thought I told you to get this fixed. Barnaby shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: I did get it fixed.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Then why isn't it fixed?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: New car assignment. Dan, at a loss, studies the car's interior -- it sure as  hell looks like the same car, right down to the gum on th sighs.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Get it fixed. Barnaby shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell is that? Dan squints through the windshield at a column of black  smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Looks like smoke.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: I am really trying to like you, Barnaby, but you  just make it so damn hard. Barnaby shrugs. The car speeds on --

dialogues.speaker: SIMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no. It can't be. . . . But it is. Will Pogue's warehouse roars away in a fire to beat all fires. Out front, police and firemen jostle shou with newscasters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sims climbs from the car to stare in appalled silence at  the blaze. Barnaby climbs from the car to stand cheerfull

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Fire started in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: You knew about this?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Car's inside, though, so this is definitely the  place.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: How do you know this?  Barnaby shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Daniels called it in. Too bad they couldn't get  those locks off, before the building went. Gonna lose a l

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Barnaby.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: I'm not sure there's a legal precedent for arresting  my partner for withholding evidence, but I am going to ch books. B.g., Perkins watches the blaze, watches Sims and Barnaby taking it all in with an impassive expression. A REPORTER into Sims' face.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Detective, is it true this is the suspected lair  of kidnappers?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Isn't it true, Detective, that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn streaks the sky. Will drives down a dirt road, omino silent. Emily sucks on a cigarette, blows smoke out the o the deserted surroundings warily.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: A speech class could do wonders for you. Maybe instill  some of that inner confidence needed to carry on a conver He keeps driving -- we're talking past the middle of nowh here -- the landscape grows more and more barren.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Want to tell me where we're going? No response. Emily is winding tighter and tighter.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice place to hide a body. Not even a peep.  She stubs out her cigarette, glares at the open window.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How can anyone live without air conditioning? He turns into an abandoned field. She rolls up her window, surreptitiously glides her finge across the door lock -- pushes it down. He stops the car, shuts off the ignition, turns to rummag in the duffel bag.  She slams him hard with her elbow, hits him again to keep him down, lunges across him to knock his door open -- He's coming up -- she kicks him, sending him backwards ou the door -- kicks again, to send him all the way out -- Will hits dirt as she slams the door, locks it, slides in the driver's seat, and reaches for the ignition --  No key. Will, rising stiffly, jingles the car keys outside the wi and smiles, grim.  She punches the ignition switch --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Open the door. She punches the ignition switch again. It pops free. She  reaches for its wires. Will winces -- he did not want to do this -- doubles up  his fist, and punches a hole through the driver's side wi Emily lunges backwards, out of reach, into the passenger  seat, still holding the limp ignition.  He unlocks and opens the driver's side door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What the hell do you think you're doing? Emily is breathing hard, tensed to kick him again.  Seconds tick by. She relaxes -- barely.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Will reaches cautiously into the car to lift a running sh from the floorboard -- what he dropped when the assault b it for her inspection. Emily, pale, eyes it, him.  He looks pointedly at the driver's seat, raises a brow in a question.  She bites her lip, nods, gathering herself into a small  ball as he sits gingerly on the glass littered driver's s his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It's six o'clock.  This means nothing to Emily. Lacing up, he shoots her a  skeptical glance.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I run at six o'clock.  She bites her lip harder. Will lifts the limp ignition an studies it, her, pops the hood and climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Now what are you doing?  He jerks the distributor cap and pockets it, before limpi down the road at a slow lope.  Emily watches him go in consternation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, bloody but unbent, doggedly runs, ignoring Emily,  who trots by his side, puffing a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You're angry. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well what did you expect me to think? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. He shoots her an appalled glance.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: For beating the crap out of me, or my car?  Emily smiles, winsome charm.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: How can I make it up to you?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Go home.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'd love to do that for you, but then I'd have to  explain about how you stole my car.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'll buy it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'll buy the damn car.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: But I love that car. He seethes.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What? A slow drizzle is beginning. Will, breathing hard, stops  and braces his hands against his knees. Emily looks him u a pull off her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: For a runner, you're not in very good shape.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand dollars. It's used.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Cash. His jaw tightens.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Fine. Will picks up the pace. Emily, fascinated, follows.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You've got fifty thousand dollars cash?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: On you?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: How barbaric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's Porsche sits outside the dingy motel structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily hums, toweling her hair. Will taps the phone, impat as hell. Emily grins.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You oughta take one. Nice to be human again.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What's the number?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What, no breakfast? Judging from his expression, it looks like breakfast is  out.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The number.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Where's my money? Will throws a packet of cash on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Five-oh-three, five-five-five, eight-nine-seven-six.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Thank you. He dials. It RINGS on the other end. Emily lifts cash and counts under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hope residence. Will extends the phone to Emily. She shrugs him off, stil counting.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hope residence. May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hope, please.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: May I ask what this is regarding?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: His daughter.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One moment please. The line CLICKS a few times.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (whispering) You are going to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Forty seven, forty eight --

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Amadeus T. Hope. To whom am I speaking?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Your daughter would like to speak to you, Mr. Hope. Will extends the phone to Emily. She takes her time. Will shakes the phone at her. She touches off the last bills.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Forty-nine, and fifty. She smiles sweetly and takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Emily?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Daddy, he made me suck his penis --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What!? Will rips the phone away and slams the receiver into its  cradle. Emily collapses on the bed, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell is the matter with you? You think  that's funny? He rips the money from her hands.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give me that!  She's still laughing. He ogles her, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look human. . . you sound human. . . but underneath  it all -- Emily stops laughing.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: We'd better leave.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You leave.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: They traced that call. Emily heads for the door. Will's not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: They didn't have time. She pauses, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: My father doesn't need time. We've got to go. Now. He stands firm. She stalks out.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Shit. This is definitely a hostage situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, driving, squints against rain splattering through  the hole in the driver's side window. Emily, smoking with is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Family reunions must be a blast at your house. She taps cigarette ash out the window -- wind and rain bl it back into the car. Will winces.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'm just having a little fun here. Don't take it  personally.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: This is fun?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: This car isn't safe anymore.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You want another car, you steal your own.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I have a car. It happens to be in your  garage. They drive in stony silence --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Lemme let you in on a little secret, Princess. The  cars I steal are business. Not fun. Not boredom. Not rich or life on the wild side. Business.  He's pissed. Emily laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I like you.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What do you do to people you don't like? Will sighs, swerves to the curb, turns to her, engine idl

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I don't like being chased by police. I don't  like police coming to my door. I don't like strangers in I don't like strangers in my car. I don't like strangers, Emily studies him with a clear steady gaze.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I'm sure you're a real nice girl, though you've  got a few problems and a real strange sense of humor, but ask for you, I don't want you, I don't need you, and I do you. I want off this ride.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Pay me for my car, and I'm gone.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What? Emily shoots him a look. His jaw tightens.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas Perkins' discreet automobile -- tinted windows, Or plates -- sits in the motel parking lot Emily and Will ju And past the car, through the motel office window, you ca see Perkins conversing with a very pale motel office cler a registration book, no questions asked, for Thomas to ex

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not night, but it's damn dark, what with rain and cl A gaudy neon light flashes welcome at the interstate. Flu the gloom above gas pumps and semis. Occasional burly fig slickers for the yellow glow of a coffee shop. Will and Emily stand in shadow by the Porsche. Will casts a doubtful glance around -- Emily extends her hand.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Well, have a good life. Will awkwardly accepts the handshake.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Same to you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: And lose that car -- Will opens his mouth to protest --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just for a while. Park it somewhere. And stay away  from phones. Trust me on this. She strides away, a slim, erect figure in the gloom -- lo suddenly, awfully frail and abandoned. Will frowns, a hin touches his bruised jaw and eyes his broken window.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Who am I kidding? She can take care of herself. He shakes his head -- Emily turns --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Hey, what's your name? Will pauses, indecisive -- Emily (CONT'D) Never mind. Probably better if I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Right. He watches, until she disappears around a corner --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will collapses into the Porsche's rain soaked seat, grima at the wet and the hanging ignition, then starts the car the highway. But he checks the rearview mirror one last t truck stop lights fade away into the gloom.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Emily Hope. And he breathes a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusk is falling as Will's Porsche turns up a dirt drive  and halts at an old gate --  Will climbs out to unlock a rusty key lock on an old chai swings the gate open, drives through, climbs out to reloc up the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will follows the drive through trees, an overgrown field, around a bend -- there's an old dilapidated farmhouse and ahead. He stops at the barn and clicks his trusty garage door op -- the barn door rolls back on tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the barn's similar to Will's Portland warehouse:  illuminated by overhead flourescents, a clean, if dusty, couple cars under dusty covers.  Will climbs wearily from the Porsche, pats its side affec and heads out the side door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- making his way to the old farmhouse --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big old place, dusty and unused. But the utilities work -- Will swings into the kitchen, flicks on lights, dials shakes his head --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous. And continues dialing. He drags a coffee maker from under the counter, rinses as he listens to the phone RING on th

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Joe. I'm not here. Leave a message. Will sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, rain soaked and looking less than able to pay for  a cup of coffee, sits at the counter wearing a pair of la sipping the aforementioned coffee and studying a map. The WAITRESS shoots her a suspicious glance, ambles up to refill her cup and smack a bill on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Lotta glare on the road today, is there? She indicates the rain swept night outside the windows.  Emily touches her sunglasses and laughs, self conscious.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Oh, these. The waitress waits for Emily to take off the sunglasses.  Emily doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is very embarrassing -- Emily touches a finger to the skin beneath her sunglasses -- implying a black eye -- shrugs, lifts her coffee cup, over elbow into full view --  In two seconds flat, the waitress goes from smart ass to  sympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Do you need help? Emily casts her gaze around the room, smiles wryly.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Do you know any of these people? I hate to just  ask a stranger, and I guess they have rules about people along, but. . . Do you know anyone, a nice guy maybe, who be willing to give someone a lift out of town?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Where do you want to go? Emily It doesn't matter where, it just needs to be tonight.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: You just sit right here, honey, i'll be right back. The waitress stiff legs it to a table and whispers to tru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will revels under a hot shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gate to the drive hangs open. A car approaches -- a very expensive car with tinted wind and Oregon plates -- headlights off, it parks out of sigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guessed it: Thomas Perkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrubbed and dressed in a robe, Will pours himself a cup  of coffee, ambles into the spartan living room, switches lifts a phone, dials, and listens to it RING on the other a remote control and switches on the MUTED TV.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Joe. I'm not here. Leave a message. Will frowns, hangs up, and relaxes into a chair to stare  at the TV. Boring. He flips channels --  Jerks forward in his chair, and switches back a channel  to stare in horror at -- The TV screen shows an anchorman, the warehouse fire, a  charred Mercedes, more fire -- Will's jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's high school yearbook photo flashes by, a picture  of Emily --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Shit shit shit.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Interesting viewing?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Jesus! Will spins to stare at Thomas Perkins, who steps silently into the room.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: I'm Uncle Tom. Who the fuck are you? Perkins holds up photocopies of mortgage deeds, studies  one in mock annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: William Pogue, who owns a warehouse in Portland,  Oregon --  Studying another photocopy --

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- William Danny, who owns a farm in Denton*, Washington? or maybe William Baker, who owns another warehouse -- you don't you? -- in Seattle, Washington. Perkins lowers the papers.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll just call you William. Now, William, where's  Emily Hope?  Perkins brings out a gun and casually begins screwing a  silencer into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing beside a rumbling semi truck, the waitress embra Emily and shoves a bag into her hands.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: There's food in here, to hold you over.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thank you Norma.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Don't even think twice about it. You just get yourself  somewhere safe. Emily gives her a hug, shoves bills into her big waitress pockets, and swings up into the truck cab.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Now blast you, I told you --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You take that money, Norma. It's all I've got to  give you, and money isn't enough. Emily slams the cab door, waves, and the semi rumbles out of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma, the waitress, is wiping down a deserted counter,  when Will, face cut up and a bit wild around the eyes, st a really nice suit.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Coffee, Hon?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a girl. Norma looks Will up and down, not liking what she sees.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She may have come in here. About yeah high, such  and such hair, thin, kinda delicate looking?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: She's gone. Will sighs in relief.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You've seen her. Do you know where she went?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Somewhere you can't get your lousy hands on her,  is where. Don't let the door hit your ass on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Bobby? Joe? The place is not entirely deserted -- two very burly TRUC glance up from their booth.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: Norma, you need something?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: This gentleman is looking for the little girl Mike  gave a ride to -- She indicates Will with her chin --

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: That so? The truckers are rising -- rising being an understatement -- to approach Will.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: He the one gave her that black eye? Norma's got her hands on her hips, staring Will down.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute --

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: I think maybe we need to have a talk outside, Son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily wakes up, ensconced in the bed of the truck cab, as MIKE the trucker climbs into the cab with two styrofoam c

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Morning. Want some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thanks. He hands it back to her and she cracks its cover to happi breathe in steam, before taking a sip.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Your eye looks pretty good. Thomas Perkins' tinted windows car pulls into the lot out

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'm a fast healer. She sets the cup down and crawls to the front of the cab, to get a better look -- it is definitely Thomas's car. Sh Mike frowns at the car.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Someone you know? She nods, tired, and drags on her shoes. Mike's glowering at the car.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You don't have to go out there. Emily gives him a tired smile and a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride and the coffee, Mike. I'll be  okay. She drops down out of the cab. Mike shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Why do they always go back, I wonder? Nice pretty  girl, could have anyone she wanted, and she goes back to eye patrol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily braces her shoulders and walks towards Thomas's car

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Aw, well, it was a fun ride, Em. She sighs, and opens the passenger door. Will glares at her from the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Get in.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Fuck you. You burned my car! She whirls and stalks back towards the truck.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I what!? He slams out and stands there, breathing hard. She turns, glaring.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No wonder you were in such a hurry to get out of  there. You torched the place!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The hell I did. More likely one of your relatives  came to visit. She stares at the car, his suit --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Where's Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: In the last twenty-four hours, I've been beaten  up by three people, threatened with a gun, insulted by a and I had to run naked through the woods. So I'm not in t to hold this conversation in the god damned rain. Now get car.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You ran naked through the woods? She glances at her watch: five thirty.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Wow. It's not even six o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily smokes like a fiend. Will drives by reflex.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'm not going back.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The hell you aren't.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You wouldn't be in this mess, if you hadn't gone  around making a bunch of phone calls. The car's cellular phone rings. Will stares at it, appall Emily eyes it, curious.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Don't answer that.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Who is it? Silence. Will's jaw works.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Uncle Tom? Uncle Tom is calling you on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs, delighted. He glares.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I'd known the fucking marines were on my ass  -- but no. It wasn't the marines. It was Uncle Tom, a muc frightening individual. Where the hell did you think you going?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Fort Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh, that explains everything.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: If you must know, I was going to visit a priest. Will snorts.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Well now you're going to visit a policeman. Who  the hell is Uncle Tom? Emily stares around the car in fascination.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I can't believe you stole Uncle Thomas's car. And  his clothes. How did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I ran.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You outran Uncle Tom?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: He wasn't counting on me jumping through that plate  glass window. She reaches up to touch one of his facial nicks.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: But how -- Will shoots her a deprecating glance, grits his teeth --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The clothes were in the car. He's waiting for an explanation, seething. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: He's not really my uncle, that's just what I call  him. He rubs his eyes, tired to death of subterfuge. She sighs

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uncle Tom does clean up for my father.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: He's a janitor. Why didn't I think of that. Will jerks the steering wheel, straightening the car's pa out on the road.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: When's the last time you got some sleep? He grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, I bet you haven't slept at all. You can't  even stay on the road.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I can stay on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perkins' car screeches off the road -- slamming to a halt amid flying pebbles and mud.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Uncle Tom is a hit man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will stares, horrified, at Emily.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Then I wish to hell you'd tell me what "exactly"  Uncle Tom is.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Okay, he's a hit man. Will plunges off the shoulder, through weeds and mud, ont the feeder road.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I have to make a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will listens grimly to Joe's answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Joe. I'm not here. Leave a message. Will hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Jesus, Joe, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Joe stands at the common phone, amidst the glamour  and glitz of a holding cell.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but the number you have dialed is disconnected or no longer in service at this time. If you feel you hav this recording in error -- Joe drops the phone into its cradle.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Damn. Looks like I'm walking. A gnarled VISITOR laughs.

dialogues.speaker: VISITOR
dialogues.text: Joe, you miser, why don't you cough up for a cab?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Already had to pay the damn fine.  A GUARD clangs the cell door.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: This ain't a hotel, you know, Pogue. You going or  staying?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm going. Hold your britches. Joe shambles out.

dialogues.speaker: VISITOR
dialogues.text: Damn idiot's going to walk. Crazy assed white son  of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It truly is a viewing room, in every sense of the word.  Amadeus sits in a massive chair, watching a newscaster ha the enormous TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is it true Emily Hope, daughter of billionaire Amadeus  T. Hope the Third, has been missing for three days?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No comment.
