dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is it true the recent grounding of a river barge  was a failed attempt -- Amadeus snaps off the telecast, stares at the dark screen Thomas rises silently and refills their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Do you relize how embarrassing it is to call a bank  president and tell him you need one million dollars repla Thomas drops ice in the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you realize there are eleven news vans parked  outside this residence?  Thomas hands Amadeus a drink. Amadeus sips, brooding.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Privacy, Thomas, is a rare commodity.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Amadeus, it's Emily.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: That's no longer an issue. Someone must take public  responsibility for this fiasco -- that someone will not b She's in Washington? Perkins nods. Amadeus shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please tell me we aren't involving the Bureau in  this.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: It's unconfirmed. It will remain unconfirmed.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Is there any way we can --  Amadeus gestures helplessly at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Short of killing everyone in the news departments? Amadeus considers the possibilities --

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. Amadeus sighs, strokes one of his Bonsai.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: They're so perfect. So controlled. Perkins' face twitches.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Will you permit me to make an observation, Amadeus?

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Certainly, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Emily is not a plant.  Amadeus frowns.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just an observation. Amadeus turns the tree to a more complimentary angle.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: I'm experiencing the strangest emotions, Thomas.  Relief. And shame. Because I thought my daughter was dead He strokes the moss at the plant's base.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- and the thought was oddly comforting. I suppose  that makes me a terrible person. Perkins doesn't say a word. Amadeus sighs.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't care how you do it. Shut the circus down. Thomas nods and heads for the door, leaving -- Thomas tur to the right.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thomas?  Thomas pauses.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My father was rarely present, while I was growing  up, yet I didn't terrorize every living soul I came in co Thomas's eyes are sad in that hard masked face of his.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: I'm not judging you, Amadeus.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: No. Just making an observation. And Thomas is gone, leaving Amadeus alone in that big, be perfectly controlled, and very empty room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to talk grease and engine parts, "Joe's Auto  Parts" is sacred, if grimy, ground. The phone is RINGING. the worse for his visit with the authorities, not to ment outside the window and unlocks the shop door. The answeri on.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Joe. I'm not here. Leave a message. The door JANGLES as Joe pushes in. The machine beeps. He  stumps across the room to pick up, just as the caller han

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I hate it when they do that. Sighing, he pulls a bottle from under the cash register,  takes a long pull, and collapses onto a beat up stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Sims studies reports, reading each sheet, setting it  aside, and wearily going on to the nEXT. He pauses.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Barnaby? You see this DUI report? Barnaby, at the next desk, glances up.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: You mean that old guy Pogue?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Did it occur to you, this old guy Pogue, who was  pulled over in the vicinity of a warehouse that just happ belong to a suspect named Pogue, might be a relative?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Sure?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's his uncle.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: His uncle?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sims stares ceilingward, praying for patience.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Barnaby, were you going to tell me this?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I probably would have gotten around to it. Sims struggles into his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Barnaby, I am really trying to like you.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: We going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Yeah, Barnaby, I thought we might pay a visit to  Mr. Pogue's uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily comes out of the bathroom, wearing a towel and rubb her hair with another, smoking a cigarette.  The key rattles and Will stalks in, soaked, halts dead.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Did you get him?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Who? He settles warily into a chair, as far from her as physic possible -- by the door.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Whoever it is you keep calling.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You take too many damn showers. She grabs her clothes off the floor and stalks into the  bathroom, leaving the door partially ajar.  Will, uncomfortable as hell, tries to ignore flashes of  flesh, as she walks back and forth in there, to the accom and sliding material.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there really a priest?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: The nuns at school used to make us go to church  -- which was boring as hell -- so I used to go to confess to shock the priests. Told 'em I slept with all these arm and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What's so shocking about that?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I was nine. She comes out of the bathroom, tosses herself on the bed, sniffs her shirt sleeve, grimaces, shuts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God I hate dirty clothes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: These priests all believed a nine year old girl  was sleeping with army guys?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I think Father Douglas is the only one who caught  on. She shuts her eyes. He shuts his eyes.  He puts his feet up on the table.  Shifts. Shifts again. Opens his eyes. Shuts them. Emily  opens her eyes and glares.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: If the chair's so god damned uncomfortable, sleep  on the bed. Your virtue will remain intact.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm used to sleeping alone.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'll bet. All those frigging locks. She tosses back down into the pillows, turning away from  him. He turns onto his side, facing away from her.  The rain beats down.  There they both lie, wide awake.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pogue, are you planning on being a car thief all  your life?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Are you planning on being a thorn in your father's  side all your life? Stony silence. Will sighs.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going to Tahiti.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You're going to steal cars in Tahiti? That's progress.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm going to fish. And I'm going to go first class.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Oh, right. So what will you live on? Fish?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I have investments. Emily laughs -- bitter.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Here I thought I'd met an honest thief -- and you  have investments. She's really laughing now -- but it's a brittle laugh.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just like my father. Next, you'll tell me you have  a tree fetish.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Believe you me, hard as I tried, I could never fuck  someone up as bad as you're fucked up over your old man. She stops laughing. He glances over at her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't tell me I hurt your feelings. She throws back the covers, stumps out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You take the bed. I'll sleep in the chair. He shakes his head no, crosses his arms.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Chair's by the door.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Jesus, God. Look, I give you my word, I will not  leave, while you're asleep. Okay? Because I would rather get some sleep than end up somewhere dead on the highway. work? My solemn oath. He looks at her, skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell JANGLES over the door and Dan Sims walks in, Bar plodding along behind him. The only living thing in sight Shepherd in the corner -- it wags its tail.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Anybody here?

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, hold on. Sims leans down to pet the dog. Joe comes out of the back glares at the dog.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Veronica, you're supposed to bite the burglars,  not welcome them in. Veronica's tail wags harder.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What can I do you for? Dan flashes a badge.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Are you Joseph Pogue?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nope. He ain't here. Sims squints at Joe.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: When do you expect him back?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dunno. He went on a fishing trip. Maybe a week or  so.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Would you happen to know where?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: How about his nephew, William Pogue? You ever see  him around here?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Only worked here a coupla weeks. Sims gives him a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: And what would your name be?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dennis Hodges.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: You got any identification, Dennis Hodges?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nope. Sims glowers. Joe shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't drive.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: You know it's against the law to lie to a police  officer, Mr. Hodges?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Now I do. Sims slaps his card on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: You hear from Pogue, you call me.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Will do. Sims and Barnaby JANGLE out the door. Joe picks up the ca studies it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mary, and Joseph. The Shepherd flops its tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sims steams. Barnaby starts the engine.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: There is something wrong here. I don't know what,  but something is not right.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: You mean with Pogue?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: What do you mean, "Do you mean with Pogue"? Barnaby inclines his head towards Joe's Auto Parts.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: That was him back there.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: How can you tell? The station picture is shit.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Went to school with him. Sims' jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: You might have said something sooner. Barnaby shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: You want to go back and talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Excuse me, Mr. Pogue. My partner just  happened to mention. . . he won't tell us anything now.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: But I want the place watched.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Okey-dokey. Barnaby pulls out. Sims jerks his seat belt forward -- it sticks. Disgusted, he drops it, past trying to get the da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas, expressionless and immaculate as always, watches  Barnaby and Sims pull away. Beside him on the seat, the red LED on a high tech phone  monitoring device blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnaby drives, nonchalant. Dan Sims broods.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Barnaby, let me ask you a question.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: What do you think is happening here? Barnaby scratches his neck, thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: You want to know what I think? Sims is getting belligerent.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just out of curiosity, I want to know what  you think.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Well, lemme see. I think old man Hope thought his  daughter was setting him up, so he didn't get too riled, he'd just play along. Then, when the car wasn't there wit it, he got worried and called in the big guns -- that'd b Mr. Perkins. But the kidnapper we're after wasn't a kidna was a car thief -- seeing as he's Joe Pogue's nephew, and aren't into kidnapping, they're into cars. You know his d a racer? So the kid took the car, but then he found the g it, which put him in a fix. So he was trying to figure ou to do about it, without getting tangled up with the law, old lady put the finger on him and the cops showed up. Th -- skittish lot, the Pogues -- and the girl probably went -- but he forgot to take the coffee off, so the whole pla down. Now old Pogue's sweating it, 'cause he hasn't heard nephew in a while, and young Pogue and that girl are some in tarnation. Sims just stares, slack jawed. Barnaby glances at him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's what I think.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: You thought that all out.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: And you never thought to mention it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: You didn't ask. Sims collapses back into his seat, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: What makes you think the kid's a car thief?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Got busted way back, musta been about fourteen at  the time, for auto. Bad crowd he was running with, after died.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: He did. Barnaby nods.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: You'd know these things, if you were from around  here.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: You don't like me much, do you Barnaby?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: I got nothing against you. I just wonder, sometimes,  how come you're out here, instead of back in your own tow Seconds tick by as Sims considers.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: You ever been to Los Angeles, Barnaby?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAIN beats against the roof. Thunder RUMBLES and Will jer awake, stares around the room panicked, relaxes when he r he is -- And stiffens when he sees Emily's gone.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: God damn it. He struggles free of tangled bed clothes, jerks open the  door to stare out at the gray sheet of rain, and cursing,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, dashing through the rain --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Stupid stupid stupid -- The car is still there, and intact. He turns to stare at the abandoned lot.  The neon motel sign spits in the gray rain, shooting weak illumination. Even the office looks dead.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. I give you my solemn oath. Yeah, right. Stupid  stupid stupid. LIGHTNING shoots across the sky, casting everything into  black and white lines, and there, on the hill behind the still figure standing in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emily? He wipes rain off his face -- like that does any good --  and trudges up the hill through a growing stream of mud a enough, it's her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emily, what are you doing out here? She just stands there, holding the front of her shirt awa from her body to stare down at an enormous black blotch o sleets down her.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I stained my shirt.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I was playing with the god damn motel pen, and it  broke, and now I've got ink all over my shirt. Will stares at the ragged shirt -- scruffy, torn, dirty  -- he laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Emily, that shirt needs to be burned.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I hate god damn stains. Emily starts crying. He blanches, puts his hands on her  shoulders, staring at her in consternation.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, it's just a beat up old shirt. This isn't having the desired effect -- she's bawling.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll buy you a new one. Here, you can have my shirt
He's struggling out his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No no no. The rain comes and it washes the whole  world clean. It just doesn't wash the people clean. We're Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: How long have you been out here, Emily? She shrugs. He takes her hands, rubs them.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, you're cold. Come on. He tugs. She resists, rain plastering her face and hair.  He wipes a sodden strand out of her face.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anybody can change, Emily.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Like you're going to change, Will, when you get  to Tahiti?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're soaked and Emily's teeth are chattering as Will  pushes her into the motel room chair and crouches to drag and rub her feet.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: That hurts.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I bet. He grabs a discarded towel, rubs her hair.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Rain never killed anyone.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The hell it didn't. You've got to get out of these  clothes. She smiles, tired. He meets her eyes -- eyes for once can and just plain young and tired.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for not leaving. She reaches out with a cold, gentle hand, to touch his fa so close, leans forward, kisses him. . . . It's a long kiss -- before he breaks away. She frees the  first button of her shirt.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I need you.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You don't need me. You need something, but it's  not me.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Don't you ever get lonely, Will Pogue? Living behind  all your locks and chains and secrets, don't you ever nee human being?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I can't afford the stakes you play for, Emily.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yes you can, Will. Just for a moment. Just to be  human. And she kisses him again, and what he should do -- or mig regret -- doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily lies awake by Will's side in the bed, staring at th ceiling, listening to Will's soft breathing. He rolls ove smiles one of those shit eating grins everyone wears, whe with the world because they just got laid.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Hi. She's distant. Will drags clothes off a chair, frowns at  the wrinkled suit, but climbs into it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I don't want to go back. He loses a bit of the rosy glow.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Emily, it's hard truth time. I have to go back.  I have to check on someone. And you have to go back. To c this mess.  He straps on his watch. She turns to stare at the wall.  He touches her face.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would truly love to hide out here with you forever,  but that's not going to work, and you know it. For one th Uncle Tom is going to come through that door one of these kill me dead for making you suck my penis. He smiles, trying.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Fine. She grabs her clothes off the floor and drags them on, pu ignoring the stain.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: God, I could eat a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, relieved enough to be rude, speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Where the hell have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, casual, speaks into the phone.  intercut:

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jail.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Jail?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What the hell --

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Pardon me for intruding, Will, but did you know  your warehouse burned to the ground?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I ask because I don't know if you've got TV's where  you're at.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You want to know what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nope. Nope. I don't want to know. I'd rather not  know. But I thought it might be good to be sure you know.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Then I figure you'll take care of it. When're you  coming home?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm on my way.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well that's good. Things're a might peculiar around  here, though. You might want to wear a hat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'll do that, Uncle Joe. (beat) Uncle Joe, there haven't been any strangers around,  asking questions, have there? Maybe a guy in a suit?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A nice suit, or a cheap suit?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: A nice suit.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Just cops.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas smiles -- not a nice smile -- snaps off his phone  tapping device, and straightens his cuff, obscuring a mil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, shivering slightly, picks at her food, looking mis A plate of fish sits across the table from her, growing c Will slides into the booth.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You get through?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Congratulations. I ordered you the fish.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh. He eyes the congealing creature with an expression less  than rapturous, but takes a manful bite and swallows.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Said the cops have been by.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the fish?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Nothing. What I'm going to do is drop you off at  the police station. Then I'm going to get the hell out of while you go in and introduce yourself.  Emily, watching him wince his way through the fish, eyes  his plate, frowns.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What's wrong with it. Will sets down his fork with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Emily, I'm sorry. I hate fish.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You hate fish. She stares out the window -- coming to a decision here,  building up inside defenses --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think you should go to Tahiti, Will. Just get  on that plane and go. Forget all this mess -- and take a along, for insurance purposes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Am I missing something here?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Missing something? She gives him a cool stare.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm taking a lot for granted. But I thought  something happened here.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yeah, something happened here. It's called sex,  Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: And suddenly, after having sex, you seem to be thinking  I'm going to be changed into a nice person and I'm going into some police station and announce myself to the world Will isn't attempting to eat fish anymore.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't ever make that mistake, Will, of thinking  I'm a nice person, just because we had sex, because if th thing I'm not, it's nice. Will's sitting there, waiting for the punch line. It does come. The silence grows.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant, Will. He stares at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: There's no way.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Not last night. Before last night.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: How -- oh, shit.  He's working through it, adjusting -- comes back at her  just as tough as she's coming at him.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can live with that. Ouch -- she didn't expect that -- she recovers fast.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who? She hits him with a hard, cold stare -- these are the big guns.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't really remember.  She pulls out a cigarette, lights up.  Will stares at it, at her, the implications sinking in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blows smoke, a thin cloud growing between them. Will Emily?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What, you're still here?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No. You're right. I think it's time I go. He stands stiffly and stalks for the door. Emily watches him go with a crooked, pained smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas Perkins strolls to the door of the shop, sparing  a casual glance for the undercover car outside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weary detective watches Joe's place, Will's high school yearbook photo on the seat beside him, and, unfortunately doesn't know, or care, who Thomas Perkins is, and spares glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door JANGLES and Thomas strolls to the counter. The  German Shepherd flops its tail against the wall. Joe, beh glances up, studies Perkins' suit.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry, I'm closed.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Joseph Pogue?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He ain't here. Thomas Really? Then perhaps you can tell me where he is?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Got no idea. You wanna leave a message, though,  I'll see he gets it when he comes back. Thomas slides a fifty dollar bill onto the counter. Thomas I would like very much to speak with him. Joe eyes the money.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's too bad, 'cause he ain't here. Thomas's eyes narrow and he retracts the fifty.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Mr. Pogue, you may not want my money, but you are  going to speak to me. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps you don't understand, Mr. Pogue. I'm very  serious.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I told you, Joe Pogue ain't here. Thomas pulls a gun (silenced) from his shoulder holster,  turns, and shoots the German Shepherd dead.

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Veronica?

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: As I said, Mr. Pogue, I'm very serious. Joe wobbles around the counter's edge, not quite believin that old dog is dead.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, Veronica?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will drives, seriously pissed, passing Highway Five South signs too fast -- and then it hits him.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: She's lying.  He jerks the wheel and screeches to a halt on the shoulde -- which gets him an unfriendly HORN blast from the car b laughs, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Man, she is good. Those poor priests. And then he sobers.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If she's not lying, you are about to make one hell  of a fool of yourself, William Pogue. He stares out the window, drumming his fingers on the whe Drumming drumming drumming --

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck it. He spins the wheel and makes a very illegal U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will rings the bell, shifts feet a few times, waiting. Th RECTORY PRIEST opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Father Douglas? The Priest studies Will, who's not up to boy scout standa today -- in fact, Will resembles a seriously scruffy char

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, he's unavailable. Perhaps you could tell  me what this is regarding?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, I need to speak to Father Douglas personally.  Could you tell me where he went? The priest checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: He should be back in a couple of hours, if you'd  like to come back. The priest starts to shut the door -- starts, only, becau Will blocks it.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: This is urgent.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: If it's urgent, you can talk to me. Will's losing patience.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, I need to speak to Father Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: Then I can't help you. The priest starts to shut the door again --  Will strong arms the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Look you, I need to speak to Father Douglas, and  I need to speak to him now. The priest blanches.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: Father Douglas is taking confessions.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will Pogue's footsteps echo, slap slap slap, across the  hard floor. It's an intimidating church, but he's not int right now, he's into getting to the confessional. Still - and shoots a token knee bend at the alter, old habits dyi At the confessional, there's a line. He pauses, less sure of himself, takes his place at the end.  And way up there, at the front of the line, there are two confessionals. He studies them.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What now? A WOMAN in front of him turns.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Nothing. Sorry. She eyes his wrinkled clothing, before turning a stiff ba on him.  Nothing for it, he waits -- receiving odd glances from li old ladies ahead of and behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rectory priest dials an old fashioned, black, rotary  phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's next in line. An elderly woman steps from one of  the confessionals. He plunges in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits awkwardly in the booth. The shade rolls back.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Are you Father Douglas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRIEST clears his throat -- a hint. Will crosses hims

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Father, for I have sinned repeatedly  and it's been years since my last confession, but if you Father Douglas, I don't want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: May I ask why, then, you're here?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a girl. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So if you could just tell me --

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Did you say you were looking for a girl?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Uh, maybe I should explain --

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Next door. Will boggles.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Next door.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: A girl?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: You'll find Father Douglas in the next confessional.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh. Uh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Unless, of course, you'd like to take advantage  of the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, I'll just be going now. Will reaches for the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, crimson faced, takes his place at the end of the li again. He's getting truly curious glances from waiting co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's first in line again. An elderly woman steps from  the confessional he entered the first time. Drat! He pret shifts his weight, staring at the second confessional.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Come on, come on -- A WOMAN behind him taps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I think it's free now.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Uh, no, you go ahead. I'm waiting for the next one. She ogles him, before going ahead. He's embarrassed as he getting stares, standing there, trying to be cool. A woma the second confessional and he bolts for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police cruiser pulls to the curb. As the COP steps from the cruiser, the rectory priest Will had the doorway alte forward to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits awkwardly in the booth, relieved to be off disp -- until the shade rolls back.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Father Douglas? The PRIEST coughs, a hint. Will genuflects -- stops himse

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, the guy next door said you were Father Douglas,  and I've got to talk to Father Douglas, so you either are not Father Douglas.  Silence. Will starts to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you are, I need to talk to you. If you aren't,  just tell me where Father Douglas is -- I'll get out of y and you won't have to worry about me till last rites. It is, by the way, FATHER DOUGLAS.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: It might be wise to see me sooner than that.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Are you Father Douglas, or aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I'll be through here in an hour. Perhaps we could  speak at that time?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You're Father Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Yes. Will expels a big sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I have a message for Emily Hope. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You do know Emily Hope?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Are you Catholic?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What does that have to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Answer the question, please. Will glances around guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Then you know I can't answer your question. Will's about had it with obstacles. He rips out paper and pen, and scribbles.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Fine. I'm writing down an address and phone number.  And if you should happen to see Emily Hope, you tell her reached here for the next twenty-four hours. And then I'm Will shoves the paper through the grill.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, and Father? Tell her I thought she was tougher  than this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, stepping out of the confessional, stops dead when  he sees the rectory priest approaching with the COP.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Aw, shit.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: That's him, officer. Will, looking for somewhere, anywhere, to hide, ducks bac into the confessional.  The confession crowd is wild with anticipation.  The cop comes to a dead stop outside the confessional.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: I can't go in there. The rectory priest raps on the door.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: Young man, come out of there immediately! No answer.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you hear me, young man? I said come out! Father Douglas, looking holier than God, steps from the  confessional, to the further excitement of the crowd --

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: What is the meaning of this? The cop pales -- he wasn't prepared for a stand off with  God.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: The man inside --

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Is a confessor. Since it is not, as far as I know,  yet a crime to attend confession, we are not yet in the h dragging confessors out of the booth. Am I clear, Father

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: Very, Father Douglas. Father Douglas turns to the cop.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming. Your services won't be necessary  today. The cop nods, gulps, and goes. Father Douglas turns to th rectory priest.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you care to explain? The rectory priest falters, casts an anxious glance at th avid spectators -- at this point, no one is entering eith He lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: I was concerned for your safety, and. . .  (oh, this is going to sound bad)

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I called the police.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I see. The rectory priest shoots a dour glance at the booth.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: He was quite forceful. Father Douglas sighs, opens the confessional door. Will  and he lock eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: It was good seeing you again, William.  Will reacts, eyes narrowing momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Right. Good seeing you again, Father. Will steps awkwardly from the booth.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: And William?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Ten Hail Marys, ten Our Fathers. Will's jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You may go.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Right. Will GOES. Father Douglas turns back to the rectory pries

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a reflection of Joe: old, worn -- too much  bad news has passed through here, leaving behind a yellow of loss that clings to every item in the room. Joe himsel too good right now either -- probably because Thomas Perk the crap out of him. Thomas pauses. Joe coughs. Thomas lifts Joe's bottle and  offers Joe a swig, which Joe takes thankfully.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Joe, you have to understand, I don't enjoy beating  up old men. Especially military men like yourself. But yo is in possession of something I must find.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don't know where he is. Haven't heard from him.  In days.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Really, Joe. Perkins gently removes the bottle from Joe's hands.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We both know you're lying. Joe reaches pleadingly after the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Please --

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Sorry, Joe.  Thomas hits him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will stands in the shadows, watching the cop study Will's "borrowed" automobile.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What is this, pick on Will Pogue week? The cop eyes the out of state plate, scribbles the number on a pad, lifts his radio mike.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I promise to say the hail marys, I promise  to say the our fathers, hell, I promise to confess, next I get, if that bozo just walks away from the car. Honest. confession. And no more cars. Not ever. The cop's radio SQUAWKS, the cop hops into his cruiser,  turns on his SIREN, and screams out of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're kidding? Thunder rumbles. Will casts an appalled glance at the sky

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's screaming down the highway, muttering under his br

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hail Mary, full of grace. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily sits on a rock, staring into space, as dark clouds  rumble past. Father Douglas walks up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I have a message for you. Emily covers her face with her hands.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Aw, shit. Father Douglas drops Will's paper into Emily's lap.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: There's a phone in the rectory. You may use it. He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Don't you judge me. He turns back.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I don't judge you, Emily. That's not my job.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Then what do you call this superior attitude?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frustration? What did you tell him, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. It didn't work. Father Douglas laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: He said he thought you were tougher than this.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Shit shit shit. Father Douglas raises his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry, Father.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: We'll make a Catholic out of you yet, Emily. Emily shakes her head, almost smiles at the old joke.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emily, that young man is in a great deal of trouble  because of you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It's not like he's a saint, Father. He did steal  a car. A lot of cars.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: That he did. I have to return. Will you be all right?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'll be fine. Father Douglas starts down the path, pauses, and turns.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Oh, and Emily?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: He appeared to have a great deal of -- character. Emily watches Father Douglas disappear down the path.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: TouchГ©, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily squints at the number on Will's paper, lifts the ph dials -- and hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I can't do this. She picks up. Hangs up. Picks up. A grotesque crucifix stares down at her from the wall. Sh glares back at it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't do this, all right! The crucifix glowers -- no, it's not all right.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Same to you, buddy. But she picks up and angrily dials, glaring at the crucif the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is not a good idea. You know that. The phone RINGS on the other end, and is picked up by Tho Perkins.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Joe's Auto Parts. Emily freezes.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello? She hangs up gently, backs slowly from the phone, turns,  and bolts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is definitely looking the worse for wear. Thomas hang up the phone, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: We should be expecting company soon now.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Coulda been anybody.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: I doubt it. Perkins gives Joe a good whack -- enough to put him out,  which is a damn hard whack.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rectory priest huffs into the study to ogle Father Do

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: Are you aware a young woman just drove off in the  Church sedan?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Yes. I gave her the keys. The rectory priest pauses, reassessing.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: She appeared rather distraught.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I believe she was, yes.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: Should we. . . ?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: No, Michael. We should not. Father Douglas drapes an arm around the rectory priest's  shoulders, walks him gently towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Michael, police are only men. Around here, we rely  on God to sort things out.

dialogues.speaker: RECTORY PRIEST
dialogues.text: Yes, Douglas, but -- Father Douglas raises a finger to hush him.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: No buts, Michael. I learned a long time ago, his  way is the best way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will saunters up the street, just a casual guy in a baseb cap and sunglasses, just ambling along to pick up some pa -- and pushes through the front door of Joe's Auto Parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop in the under cover car glances at him, at the pic but hey, nobody actually looks like their high school yea Not really. And the cop goes back to his long wait for no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will slouches in. No one around.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Joe? Silence. Will glances at Veronica's corner -- empty.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Joe? Veronica? Silence. He strides to the cash register --

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 'Bout time you walked that dog.  -- bangs the cash drawer open -- too much cash in there.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God damn it, Joe, I keep telling you, don't leave  this stuff around. He opens the safe in the cupboard below the register, tak a passport out, stashes it in his front pocket, grabs cas drawer and stows it in the safe --

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you robbing the place? Will spins to see Perkins in the doorway to the back.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Uncle Tom.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Very good. Do you know what Uncle Tom wants?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I didn't make her suck my penis, if that's the next  question.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Her father will be relieved to hear that. Perkins motions.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In back, please.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: It's not a request.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Sorry. Perkins shoots Will in the leg -- the gun's silenced, nat

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Now. Shall we try again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church sedan, if the logo is any indication, screams  into the parking lot -- which actually does get the under attention -- and a very recognizable Emily falls out of t to get to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The undercover detective scrabbles for his radio.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERCOVER DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, I've got Emily Hope here -- I need  back up, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily slams in the door, knocking the jangling bells clea off their hook, glances around -- no one there -- sees th and keeps going -- To stop dead in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING QUARTERS
dialogues.text: Joe's still out cold. Will, however, is very much awake,  not to mention in pain, leaning against a table, his leg holds his gun at a nonchalant angle, addressing Will.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: A medical team could --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thomas. Perkins turns to study Emily.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: You did do it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yes. Let them go.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: It would be best if you waited in the car, Emily.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It's just a game, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Sometimes, the game becomes real. That's something  I forgot to teach you, evidently.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: There's a cop outside, Thomas, and his friends are  on their way.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Emily --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Shut up, Will. Emily fingers the necklace at her throat -- Thomas's gift of long ago.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: In sixty seconds, that won't be a problem. Never  start something you can't finish, Emily.  Will is reaching under the table -- cautious, so cautious not to attract Perkins' attention with his movement -- be Will is stretching fingers for is a good old fashioned re to the bottom of the table -- Perkins turns and draws down on Will --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Uncle Tom! And she's bringing a gun up to bear on Thomas -- staring  at his face --

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: A)        Emily, a little girl, crying at her mother's fu -- Amadeus, too distracted to notice a three year old chi taking her hand, leading her away -- B)        Emily, a little girl, running down the steps of that big, empty, Hope house --

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Uncle Tom! And Thomas lifting her up in the air to swing her around  while she laughs -- C)        Amadeus, studying a young Emily --

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Emily, you're growing too attached to Thomas. It's  important you understand what Thomas does for this family D)        Emily, teenaged, crying in a car, as Thomas sli into the driver's seat

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: But you hurt people!

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: Emily, that's my job.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Why do you hurt people --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is slowing down as Thomas goes combat, eyes fl instinct taking over, turning and drawing on Emily -- Her finger isn't moving on the trigger, isn't responding, because she is not going to be able to shoot this man --  But he is able, is going, to shoot her, his finger  tightening -- and then he meets her eyes -- Combat mode switches off, and he's human again, staring  at her, knowing her, Emily, not the enemy --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I love you, Uncle Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: PERKINS
dialogues.text: I love you too, Emily. All those shared years, all those lessons, and in that lo he's saying good-bye, because they both know what the las Thomas spins away, drawing down on Will --

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: Will draws that old revolver, firing -- missing -- Thomas pulls the trigger, hitting Will in the shoulder,  spinning him back against the wall --

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: And Emily raises her gun and fires ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cop cars screaming into the lot, cops coming out guns dra and heading inside, as GUNSHOTS blast O.S. --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas takes a solid hit -- Emily's -- as he fires at Wil again, the hit throwing his aim off -- the bullet sluggin as Emily ducks, hands over her ears, screaming --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No no no no no -- Will firing and this time he isn't missing --  Thomas falling, falling, as Cops come in the door, weapon drawn --

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Freeze! Will turning in surprise -- not a good move, holding a gu

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Not me -- -- dropping the gun as a cop squeezes the trigger --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Stop it -- Will slamming back into the wall, surprised, because he  just took another bullet in the shoulder --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Stop it! He didn't do anything! And Thomas still falling, to land and bounce, land and bo land and lie still --

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm hit? Cops grabbing Will, SIRENS Screaming b.g. -- Emily crawling to Thomas, crying --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Uncle Tom! God no no no -- Will looking back at her as she raises her tear streaked  face and mouths "Please" --  Uniforms surrounding her, AD LIBBING are you hurt, are yo all right, where does it hurt, blocking Will out --  Emily looks down at Perkins --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I finished it, Uncle Thomas. Oh, God, I am so sorry,  I finished it, and I should never have listened to you -- And just closes her eyes, not wanting to see any more --  as Will passes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amadeus, Emily, and Father Douglas stand grave side.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Would you like to say a few words, Mr. Hope? Amadeus shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emily? Emily removes that long ago birthday necklace, and places it on the headstone, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER DOUGLAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll leave you alone with him. Father Douglas strides away, and there they are: Emily an Amadeus. Alone at last. Seconds tick by. Amadeus removes a sub-atomic speck of lint from his cuff.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Thomas was a good man.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thomas was not a good man. Thomas was an assassin.  But he was the only father I ever had.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: That would explain why you shot him in the back. She jerks, struck hard, studies him through hard, unshed  tears.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: All these years, I thought it was me. That there  was something ugly and wrong about me. And if I just trie enough, you'd care. But it's always been you. Ugly and br

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: He was my friend, God damn it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I was your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: As distasteful as you may find it, Emily, you're  still my daughter. And I'm still your father.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No. I just buried my father.  She turns and walks away, across that big expanse of deat towards waiting cars, and life. Amadeus watches her retreating back, turns away, adjusts  his cuff.

dialogues.speaker: SUIT
dialogues.text: Amadeus Thadeus Hope? Amadeus turns to face two stern faced, over-barbered, sun wearing SUITS -- i.e., federal agents.

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: Yes? The suits flash badges.

dialogues.speaker: SUIT
dialogues.text: You're under arrest for conspiracy and withholding  information related to a federal crime.

dialogues.speaker: SUIT
dialogues.text: If you'll step over to the car, Mr. Hope?

dialogues.speaker: AMADEUS
dialogues.text: What are the grounds for these charges, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: SUIT
dialogues.text: Were you aware, Mr. Hope, that Mr. Perkins kept  a ledger of his activities?  Amadeus pales. The suit cracks a grim faced smile.

dialogues.speaker: SUIT
dialogues.text: It's quite comprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sims and Barnaby lean against a limousine, much to the CH chagrin, watching Amadeus and the suits.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: They got him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Amazing. Emily, ignoring the detectives, strides to the limo, wher the chauffeur leaps to open her door.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Will we be waiting for Mr. Hope, Miss? Emily is pulling herself together, getting frosty.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No. Mr. Hope has provided his own transportation.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Miss Hope? Emily frowns at the detective.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: This is not the time or the place, Detective.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: I'm running out of times and places, Miss Hope.  And you're a little hard to reach. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Look, we know about the car.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What about the car, Detective?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: We found the car in William Pogue's warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I sold that car to Mr. Pogue.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: While you were kidnapped, you sold the car?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No. Before my abduction, I sold the car.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: This would be before Thomas Perkins abducted you,  then?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Precisely.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Miss, do you know lying to a police officer is a  crime?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm perfectly aware of that, Detective. I'm  also aware you have no case. Sims settles back on his heels to study her warily.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Actually, I have quite an interesting case, Miss  Hope. Emily smiles, winsome, charming -- the angel again.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Detective Sims, I owe you an apology. I'm sure my  father has put you through living hell -- and I'm largely for that. Please accept my apology. Sims blinks. Emily's face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However, Detective Sims, you should also be aware  I'm a superb liar.  Sims opens his mouth -- Emily raises a hand to cut him of

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Superb, Detective Sims -- and stinking filthy rich.  In other words, if you attempt to pursue this further, I your ass through the worst press campaign it has ever see will embarrass you to death, Detective Sims, and then I w you in court. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: Quite. Emily smiles, steps into the limo, and the chauffeur slam the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sims and Barnaby sit watching the limo disappear down the street, its exhaust trail dissipating until there's nothi cloud.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: What do you think, Barnaby?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: I believe her.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS
dialogues.text: So do I.  Sims casts a sideways glance at Barnaby's profile.

dialogues.speaker: SIMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I'm beginning to like you, Barnaby. Barnaby shrugs and starts the engine. Sims reaches for hi seat belt, stops, scrutinizes it. The damn thing works. H

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnaby doesn't bat an eye, just pulls away from the curb -- and Dan snaps his belt home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell JANGLES, and Emily Hope stalks in, puffing a cig Uncle Joe squints at her from behind the counter. She ext

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'm Emily Hope. Joe ignores the hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I know who you are. And I don't allow smoking in  my shop.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You have Will's winning personality, I see.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yep. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Then we ought to get along just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will leans against his Porsche -- the window's fixed --wa his planes. A cab approaches, its tires crunching gravel. He glances over his shoulder at it. It stops and Emily cl out. Will turns his back on her. She crunches up to lean against the Porsche beside him,  as the cab pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Letting that driver go might have been a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I tried calling, you know.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I didn't get the messages.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: For a month.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You called twice.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What do you want, Emily.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thought you'd be in Tahiti by now. Catching fish  you won't eat. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Decided to stick around and steal cars instead?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm retired. She lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were never pregnant, were you?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You're a damn fine liar. I just think I've had enough  of liars for the time being.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'm retired too. Will rounds on her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Jesus God, Emily. I killed a man. Because of you.  And I don't know how I can live with that. Let alone if I with that.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You don't know what sorry means. And you probably  never will. He stalks to the Porsche, drags the door open, leaving.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I know what sorry means. I know damn well what sorry  means, Will Pogue. She throws her cigarette away, hugs herself, staring off  into the growing dusk. . .

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. She fumbles a plane ticket out of her purse and throws it on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bought two tickets to Tahiti, Will Pogue. And  you can either be on that plane, or you can sit here star them for the rest of your life. Frankly, I don't give a d you choose. But I do know what sorry means. She turns and crunches away across gravel, headed for the distant terminal lights.  It's starting to rain, big wet drops out of the sky, fall down.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Are they first class tickets? Emily slaps an angry tear, or maybe it's a raindrop, away

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I said, are they first class tickets?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What do you think? Will lifts the ticket, wipes a raindrop off it, which is  quickly replaced by another, and another.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Round trip? Emily crosses her arms and shoots him a "don't push your  luck" type glare. He opens the passenger door.  She's thinking about it? He rolls his eyes.  She crunches back, climbs in.  He climbs in, starts the car. And the Porsche pulls away, crunching over gravel, turnin onto tarmac, as a plane crosses over our heads and we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
